description: From a dialectal variation of Scots whither (“to rush; bluster; hurl”), from Middle English quhediren, probably of North Germanic origin; see Old Norse hviða (“squall of wind”).

entries.meaning: (archaic, dialectal) A low roaring or rushing sound.

verbs.description: wuther (third-person singular simple present wuthers, present participle wuthering, simple past and past participle wuthered)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, archaic, dialectal) To make a rushing sound; to whizz.
